{{Infobox television | show_name = Demi Lovato: Stay Strong | image = DemiLovatoStayStrong.jpg | image_size = | image_alt = | caption = Promotional poster | genre = [[Documentary film|Documentary]] | creator = | based_on = | writer = | screenplay = | story = | director = Davi Russo<ref name=Today>{{cite web|url=http://www.today.com/news/demi-lovato-participate-live-q-tuesday-mtv-324629|work=[[Today (U.S. TV program)|Today]]|accessdate=December 25, 2015|date=March 6, 2012|author=Gael Fashingbauer Cooper|title=Demi Lovato to participate in live Q&A Tuesday on MTV}}</ref> | starring = [[Demi Lovato]] | narrated = | theme_music_composer = | country = United States | language = English | num_episodes = | producer = {{plainlist| * [[@radical.media|Samantha Storr]] * [[Dave Sirulnick]] * [[Justin Wilkes]] * Jonathan Mussman<ref name=Road>{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/videos/news/746220/demi-lovato-stay-strong-celebrating-the-road-to-recovery.jhtml|work=[[MTV]]|accessdate=December 27, 2015|date=March 7, 2012|title='Demi Lovato: Stay Strong' - Celebrating The Road To Recovery}}</ref> }} | editor = | cinematography = | runtime = 42 minutes | company = | distributor = | budget = | network = [[MTV]] | first_aired = {{film date|TV=y|2012|3|6}} | last_aired = | preceded_by = | followed_by = | website = http://www.mtv.com/videos/news/746180/demi-lovato-stay-strong-how-things-got-out-of-control.jhtml }} '''''Demi Lovato: Stay Strong''''' is a 2012 documentary film about American singer [[Demi Lovato]] which follows her recovery after leaving rehab and her return to the music industry after abrubtly cancelling her tour with the [[Jonas Brothers]], putting her career on a hiatus in order to seek treatment. It premiered on March 6, 2012 on [[MTV]].<ref name=Today /> The documentary depicts her reflecting on her road to recovery, addressing several of her emotional and physical issues, celebrating [[Thanksgiving]] with her family in 2011 and returning for the very first time to the treatment facility she retreated to back in 2010.<ref name=Video>{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/videos/news/746180/demi-lovato-stay-strong-how-things-got-out-of-control.jhtml|work=[[MTV]]|accessdate=December 25, 2015|date=March 7, 2012|title='Demi Lovato: Stay Strong' - How Things Got Out Of Control}}</ref>
Several years later in her [[YouTube]] documentary about her life and career, ''Demi Lovato: Simply Complicated'' (2017), Lovato admitted to being dishonest about the outcome of her initial treatment in ''Demi Lovato: Stay Strong'', and also revealed that she was in fact under the influence of [[cocaine]] while being interviewed about her sobriety for the documentary film.<ref name="Simply Complicated">{{cite web|title=Demi Lovato: Simply Complicated - Official Documentary|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZWTlL_w8cRA|website=''[[YouTube]]''|accessdate=October 21, 2017}}</ref><ref name="SC Billboard">{{cite news|last1=Armstrong|first1=Megan|title=The 10 Most Honest Confessions From Demi Lovato's 'Simply Complicated' YouTube Documentary|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/pop/8005791/demi-lovato-simply-complicated-documentary-youtube-best-moments|accessdate=October 22, 2017|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|date=October 18, 2017}}</ref><ref name="SC Maxim">{{cite news|title=Demi Lovato Talks About Casual Sex and Cocaine Addiction in Her Revealing 'Simply Complicated'|url=https://www.maxim.com/women/demi-lovato-talks-cocaine-casual-sex-simply-complicated-2017-10|accessdate=October 22, 2017|work=[[Maxim (magazine)|Maxim]]|date=October 22, 2017}}</ref><ref name="SC InStyle">{{cite news|last1=Fowler|first1=Brandi|title=Demi Lovato’s Childhood Bullies Were So Intense They Petitioned for Her Suicide|url=http://www.instyle.com/news/demi-lovato-simply-complicated-documentary-interview|accessdate=October 22, 2017|publisher=[[InStyle]]|date=October 17, 2017}}</ref>
==Background and production== [[File:DemiLovatoSep10 5.jpg|220px|thumbnail|left|Lovato performing during the [[List of Jonas Brothers concert tours#Live in Concert World Tour 2010|Jonas Brothers Live in Concert World Tour]] in September 2010, about two months before the singer abrubtly withdrew from the tour.]] Lovato had suffered from [[depression (mood disorder)|depression]], an eating disorder, [[self-harm]] and being [[bullying|bullied]] before she went into rehab at the age of 18.<ref name=Punch/><ref>{{cite web|title=Demi Lovato Still Has "Nightmares" About the Childhood Bullying She Endured|url=http://www.eonline.com/news/434771/demi-lovato-still-has-nightmares-about-the-childhood-bullying-she-endured|work=[[E!#E! Online|E! Online]]|accessdate=December 27, 2015|date=June 28, 2013}}</ref> On November 1, 2010, she left the [[List of Jonas Brothers concert tours#Live in Concert World Tour 2010|Jonas Brothers Live in Concert World Tour]], entering a treatment facility for "physical and emotional issues".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eonline.com/news/208889/demi-lovato-enters-treatment-center-for-issues|title=Demi Lovato Enters Treatment Center for 'Issues'|first=Natalie |last=Finn|publisher=[[E!]]. NBCUniversal|date=November 1, 2010|accessdate=March 14, 2010}}</ref> She decided to enter treatment after punching female dancer [[Beat Freaks#Alex Welch|Alex Welch]]; her management and family confronted her in a formal intervention after this incident to convince her she needed help. Lovato agreed to seek help and took "full responsibility" for the incident.<ref name=Punch>{{cite news|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Entertainment/demi-lovato-interview-teen-star-opens-bulimia-cutting/story?id=13405090&page=1|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110521143956/http://abcnews.go.com/Entertainment/demi-lovato-interview-teen-star-opens-bulimia-cutting/story?id=13405090&page=1|title=Demi Lovato Interview: Teen Star Opens Up on Bulimia, Cutting Issues|publisher=[[ABC News]]. [[American Broadcasting Company]]|last=Johnston|first=Janice|date=April 19, 2011|archivedate=May 21, 2011|accessdate=March 14, 2013}}</ref>
On January 28, 2011, Lovato completed inpatient treatment at Timberline Knolls and returned home. She acknowledged that she had suffered from [[anorexia]] and [[bulimia]], had harmed herself, and had been "self-medicating" with drugs and alcohol "like a lot of teens do to numb their pain".<ref>{{cite news|title=Demi Lovato Exclusive Interview|url=http://www.seventeen.com/celebrity/g2206/exclusive-interview-demi-lovato/|work=[[Seventeen (American magazine)|Seventeen]]|publisher=[[Hearst Corporation]]|accessdate=March 14, 2013}}</ref> In addition, Lovato said that she "basically had a [[nervous breakdown]]" and was diagnosed with [[bipolar disorder]] during her treatment.<ref name=Fox>{{cite news|title=Disney Star Demi Lovato: I'm Bipolar|url=http://www.foxnews.com/entertainment/2011/04/20/disney-star-demi-lovato-im-bipolar/|publisher=[[Fox News Channel]]. [[21st Century Fox]]|date=April 20, 2011|accessdate=March 14, 2013}}</ref> Lovato later added that she had used [[cocaine]] several times a day and smuggled cocaine onto airplanes.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.accesshollywood.com/videos/demi-lovato-admits-i-would-smuggle-cocaine-on-airplanes-exclusive-43141/ |title=Demi Lovato Admits: I Would ‘Smuggle’ Cocaine On Airplanes (Exclusive)|work=[[Access Hollywood]]|accessdate=December 25, 2015}}</ref> After finishing her treatment, Lovato returned to work on her third album in February 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1656900/demi-lovato-leaves-treatment.jhtml|title=Demi Lovato Leaves Treatment|first=Jocelyn|last=Vena|date=January 28, 2011|publisher=MTV|accessdate=March 9, 2011}}</ref> In April 2011, Lovato announced she was leaving ''[[Sonny with a Chance]]'', where she portrayed the main character Sonny Munroe, because she wanted to focus on her music career rather than acting.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20483103,00.html|title=Demi Lovato Is Leaving Sonny with a Chance |work=[[People (magazine)|People]]|date=April 19, 2011|accessdate=August 13, 2011|first=Sharon|last=Cotliar}}</ref>
Lovato's third album, [[Unbroken (Demi Lovato album)|''Unbroken'']], was released on September 20, 2011 and was met with mixed to positive reviews from [[music journalism|music critics]]. It debuted at number four on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] and was eventually certified Gold.<ref name="billboard">{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/467230/tony-bennett-85-achieves-first-no-1-album-on-billboard-200 |title=Tony Bennett, 85, Achieves First No. 1 Album on Billboard 200 |work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|last=Caulfield|first=Keith|publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]]|date=September 28, 2011|accessdate=May 20, 2013}}</ref> The [[contemporary R&B|R&B]]-infused album was preceded by Lovato's critically acclaimed top ten single "[[Skyscraper (song)|Skyscraper]]" and spawned the triple-platinum certified hit single "[[Give Your Heart a Break]]". On February 21, 2012, Lovato announced on [[Twitter]] that a television special she had worked on with [[MTV]] would premiere on March 6, 2012, while she also revealed its title ''#StayStrong'' and the promotional poster for the documentary, showing Lovato's "''Stay Strong''" wrist tattoos as well as her scars.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/2300281/demi-lovato-tweet-stay-strong-special/|title=Demi Lovato Tweets About New Special, ‘Stay Strong,’ Airing March 6 On MTV|work=[[MTV News]]|last=Anitai|first=Tamar|accessdate=December 25, 2015|date=February 21, 2012}}</ref> An official trailer was released by MTV on the same day.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/videos/news/734044/demi-lovato-stay-strong-trailer.jhtml|title='Demi Lovato: Stay Strong' Trailer|work=[[MTV]]|accessdate=December 25, 2015|date=February 21, 2012}}</ref>
==Synopsis== {{Quote box | quote = "I don't think I'm fixed. People think that you're like a car in a body shop. You go in, they fix you, and you're out. It takes constant fixing." | source = — Lovato describing her path to recovery.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/1680610/demi-lovato-stay-strong-full-episode/|title=‘Demi Lovato: Stay Strong': ‘Why Not Air All My Secrets?’|last=Vena|first=Jocelyn|publisher=[[MTV News]]|date=March 7, 2012|accessdate=December 30, 2015}}</ref> | width = 18% | align = left }}
''Demi Lovato: Stay Strong'' commences with fans shouting Lovato's first name, while waiting for her to arrive at the [[Fox Theatre (Detroit)|Fox Theatre]] in [[Detroit]] where she is about to perform on November 16, 2011.<ref name=Video /> The tour date marks the opening night of the [[A Special Night with Demi Lovato|Unbroken Tour]] and her first tour date since the sold-out ''An Evening with Demi Lovato'' two-date promotional tour that took place in September 2011.<ref>{{cite web|title=Demi Lovato NY, LA Shows Sell Out in Minutes|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/demi-lovato-ny-la-shows-228436|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|accessdate=December 30, 2015|date=August 28, 2011|last=Schillaci|first=Sophie}}</ref> Lovato starts reflecting on the rough road that led her to self-harm and addiction, while scenes of Lovato getting ready for her performance in the dressing room are interwoven featuring a short [[cameo appearance]] from her manager Phil McIntyre.<ref name=Video /> She says she "had so many issues underneath that needed to be taken care of and that "it literally ended up driving [her] insane". Shortly after, Lovato's home in [[Los Angeles]] is shown where she is seen hugging her mother Dianna Lee Hart, whereas Lovato's half-sister [[Madison De La Garza]] is also featured.<ref name=Video />
As soon as Lovato's makeup and hair is done, she is ready to go on stage and a huge audience is seen cheering for her.<ref name=Video /> Lovato confesses, "I cannot tell you that I have not thrown up since treatment. I cannot tell you I’ve not cut myself since treatment. I’m not perfect. This is a daily battle that I will face for the rest of my life."<ref name=Purpose /> She's then seen performing the track "All Night Long". Lovato reveals that her new, bigger purpose in life is to "inspire people," and "get people through their days and their problems".<ref name=Purpose/> Some interviewed fans express what they think about Lovato's recovery and how she is an inspiration to them, while praising her strength.<ref name=Purpose>{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/videos/news/746197/demi-lovato-stay-strong-finding-a-bigger-purpose.jhtml|work=[[MTV]]|accessdate=December 25, 2015|date=March 7, 2012|title='Demi Lovato: Stay Strong' - Finding 'A Bigger Purpose'}}</ref>
[[File:Demi Lovato A Special Night 1 Crop.jpg|200px|thumbnail|Lovato performing in the dress she wore when she let the "special" fan on stage, December 2011.]]
The cameras follow her home where she spends her first Thanksgiving out of treatment and Lovato explains how her eating disorder had developed. "This year I am definitely not taking any holiday for granted," she says about spending Thanksgiving with her family.<ref name=Thanksgiving>{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/videos/news/746202/demi-lovato-stay-strong-first-thanksgiving-out-of-treatment.jhtml|work=[[MTV]]|accessdate=December 26, 2015|date=March 7, 2012|title='Demi Lovato: Stay Strong' - First Thanksgiving Out Of Treatment}}</ref> After Thanksgiving, Lovato keeps thinking about what she ate on the holiday, cries about it and feels uncomfortable before going on stage.<ref name=Beautiful /> She feels sick, but still decides to perform. A small part of her performance of the song "Fix a Heart" is shown, as well as Lovato taking pictures with fans at her [[public relations|meet-and-greet]].<ref name=Beautiful />
One of her fans, a [[cancer]] survivor, tells Lovato inspired her to go to the meet-and-greet without her wig.<ref name=Huffington>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/joshua-lyon/demi-lovato_b_1322659.html|title=Demi Lovato's Long Road to Recovery|work=[[The Huffington Post]]|last=Lyon|first=Joshua|accessdate=December 27, 2015|date=June 3, 2015}}</ref><ref name=Beautiful /> Sitting in front of the piano on stage, Lovato expresses how thankful she is to be there, "because not long ago I was in a treatment facility" and she "was so scared and was so alone but I had you guys [the fans] by my side". She mentions the "beautiful, beautiful girl that I met", tells the audience why the girl went to the concert without her wig and states, "That's why I continue to do this [performing] every single day of my life no matter how hard it gets."<ref name=Beautiful /> The singer adds, "It's the people sitting in this audience and the strength that you guys possess, so just keep inspiring people 'cause you're inspiring me to stay so strong til this day. So, thank you." and starts singing her song "Together" while letting the "special" girl join her on stage to perform a duet.<ref name=Beautiful>{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/videos/news/746205/demi-lovato-stay-strong-one-beautiful-fan.jhtml|work=[[MTV]]|accessdate=December 26, 2015|date=March 7, 2012|title='Demi Lovato: Stay Strong' - One 'Beautiful' Fan}}</ref>
The singer revisits Timberline Knolls, the treatment facility in [[Lemont, Illinois|Lemont]], [[Illinois]] she entered back in 2010, for the very first time since she was released in mid-January 2011.<ref name=Timberline>{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/1680492/demi-lovato-stay-strong-rehab/|title=Demi Lovato Recalls Entering Rehab In ‘Stay Strong’|work=[[MTV News]]|last=Vena|first=Jocelyn|accessdate=December 27, 2015|date=March 5, 2012}}</ref> Lovato recalls on her way to Timberline Knolls, "The first time that I walked into Timberline Knolls, I sat there to eat my first meal, and it was chicken, rice, vegetables and milk, and I took like two or three bites of the chicken and was like 'OK, I'm done'." adding, "That’s when I realized maybe I do belong here because I can’t finish a meal."<ref name=Timberline /> She confesses about the room she stayed in during her treatment, "I got so completely vulnerable and so raw, when I even step into this room I feel naked." Showing her wrist tattoos, she reveals how meaningful they are to her and she didn't get them just to cover up the scars she had, but also because her fans kept encouraging her to stay strong while in rehab.<ref name=Timberline />
"I wish that every single person here could just live in freedom," Lovato tells the patients at Timberline Knolls while delivering a speech.<ref name=Skyscraper>{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/videos/news/746215/demi-lovato-stay-strong-demi-performs-skyscraper.jhtml|work=[[MTV]]|accessdate=December 27, 2015|date=March 7, 2012|title='Demi Lovato: Stay Strong' - Demi Performs 'Skyscraper'}}</ref> It was at Timberline Knolls where she was first diagnosed with [[bipolar disorder]].<ref name=Fox /> She admits that she didn't realise that she was ill before her treatment and used to assume that "writing seven songs in one night was normal". Bringing her guitarist and friend Mike Manning with her, Lovato gives an intimate acoustic performance of her empowering hit song "[[Skyscraper (song)|Skyscraper]]" after her speech and gets emotional, saying "Utilize your time here, 'cause this place will change your life, 'cause it changed mine."<ref name=Skyscraper />
Lovato opens up about how she realized that she could use what she was for in the treatment center "for the better".<ref name=Skyscraper /> Instead of keeping her struggles and demons to herself, she decided to share her story with the world "because some people need to hear it". She wanted to inspire others with her story and prove that no matter what people are going through at the moment, they will get through it. The acoustic "Skyscraper" rendition at Timberline Knolls flows into a piano-driven performance of the song at a concert venue and Lovato is seen going into the crowd.<ref name=Skyscraper /> The singer and her crew dance to "[[B.M.F. (Blowin' Money Fast)|B.M.F.]]" by [[Rick Ross]] in her tour bus after the concert while she acknowledges that "recovery doesn't have a day off".<ref name=Road />
==Promotion== [[File:Demi Lovato 5, 2012.jpg|200px|thumbnail|left|Lovato performing on ''[[Good Morning America]]'' in July 2012 as part of their Summer Concert Series.]] On the morning of March 6, 2012, Lovato made an appearance on [[Today (U.S. TV program)|''The Today Show'']] to promote the documentary which would premiere on MTV that night. She performed her single "[[Give Your Heart a Break]]".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.idolator.com/6209441/demi-lovato-performs-on-the-today-show|title=Demi Lovato Performs On ‘The Today Show’|last=Bain|first=Becky|date=March 6, 2012|accessdate=January 3, 2016|work=[[Idolator (website)|Idolator]]}}</ref> "I've decided to tell my story because there are a lot of young teens, girls and boys, that are dealing with the same issues that I've been through. If I'm able to use my voice to do good in the world then I definitely want to do that," she told ''Today'' anchor [[Ann Curry]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/03/06/demi-lovato-today-show-eating-disorder-stay-strong_n_1323631.html|title=Demi Lovato Previews New Eating Disorder Documentary On 'Today' Show (VIDEO)|work=[[The Huffington Post]]|accessdate=January 3, 2016|date=March 6, 2012}}</ref>
After the documentary film was premiered, Lovato immediately appeared on ''Demi Lovato: Stay Strong — The After Show'' in order to react to her documentary and do a special question-and-answer session. The show, hosted by MTV's [[Su-chin Pak|SuChin Pak]], was broadcast live from the [[One Astor Plaza|MTV Studios]] in [[Times Square]].<ref name=AfterShow>{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/1680608/demi-lovato-stay-strong-post-show/|title=Demi Lovato 'Stay Strong': Inside 'The After Show'|publisher=[[MTV News]]|accessdate=December 27, 2015|date=March 7, 2012|last=Vena|first=Jocelyn}}</ref> Fans could participate in the conversation on Twitter by tweeting the hashtag ''#StayStrong'' and ask Lovato questions by using the hashtag #AskDemi. "It feels really awesome. Doing the documentary was so interesting," she shared when talking about how she felt after releasing the documentary.<ref name=AfterShow/> She added, "I felt really vulnerable, and I still kind of do tonight. I wouldn't change it. I'm doing awesome right now. I'm living a really healthy lifestyle. It's not easy. I struggle. But each day gets easier." Lovato announced during the post-show that she would have an upcoming appearance in ''[[Punk'd]]''.<ref name=AfterShow/>
The after show also featured some unaired extra footage.<ref name=Bonus>{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/2516153/demi-lovato-tattoos/|title=Demi Lovato Talks Tattoos In ‘Stay Strong’ Bonus Clip|last=Wilson|first=Gaby|work=[[MTV News]]|accessdate=January 20, 2016|date=March 7, 2012}}</ref> In the extra footage the singer explains every story behind her tattoos, including the reason why she got the signature heart from the [[Here We Go Again (Demi Lovato album)|''Here We Go Again'']] [[cover art]] tattooed on her wrist. She states that she sees it as a unique connection with her fans who "would draw it on their wrists every day" until she left treatment.<ref name=Tattoo>{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/videos/news/746752/demi-lovato-stay-strong-tattoos.jhtml|work=[[MTV]]|accessdate=December 27, 2015|date=March 7, 2012|title='Demi Lovato: Stay Strong' - Tattoos}}</ref> Several fans featured in cameos raise their voices praising Lovato for being an anti-bullying advocate. Lovato says that people can make a difference by speaking up when they experience or witness bullying and admits that she was bullied herself, but expresses that she does not care about what [[hatred|haters]] think about her.<ref name=Cyber>{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/videos/news/746753/demi-lovato-stay-strong-cyber-bullying.jhtml|title='Demi Lovato: Stay Strong' - Cyber Bullying|work=[[MTV]]|accessdate=December 27, 2015|date=March 7, 2012}}</ref>

The '''Epic Theatre Ensemble''' is a professional [[social justice]] [[theatre company]] in [[New York City]].<ref>[http://www.edmontonjournal.com/Vern+Thiessen+returns+from+Apple+head+Workshop+West/11147168/story.html "Vern Thiessen returns from the Big Apple to head up Workshop West"]. Liz Nicholls, ''Edmonton Journa'' 06.17.2015</ref> As well staging well known traditional plays,<ref>[http://www.curtainup.com/macbethaquila-epic.html "The Bard's Famous Murdering Couple Open On Two Different Stages in One Week"]. ''Curtain Up'', Deirdre Donovan.</ref> its productions often focus on promoting engaged citizenship and social change.<ref>[http://lifestyle.inquirer.net/72814/review-hirabayashi-remembered-in-eloquent-play/ "Review: Hirabayashi remembered in eloquent play"]. ''Inquirer'', by: Peter Santilli /Associated Press / October 23, 2012</ref>
==History== The Epic Theatre Ensemble was founded in 2001 by original members Ron Russell, Melissa Friedman, Zak Berkman, James Wallert, Teri Lamm, Craig Rovere, and Shaheen Vaaz. Its work is influenced by the [[Epic Theatre]] movement.
In 2009 the Ensemble's [[remix]] of [[Shakespeare]]’s plays performed in several [[New York City Public Schools]] was awarded the [[National Arts and Humanities Youth Program Award]], then called the Coming Up Taller Award.<ref>"Epic Theatre Ensemble." American Theatre Jan. 2010: 22.</ref>
Significant productions include the 2010 rendition of [[Sarah Ruhl]]’s Passion Play<ref>Sheward, David. "Sarah Ruhl's Passion play: Epic Theatre Ensemble at the Irondale Center." Back Stage, National ed. 13 May 2010: 40.</ref><ref>[http://www.chicagostagereview.com/sarah-ruhl%E2%80%99s-passion-play-review/ "Sarah Ruhl’s “PASSION PLAY” – REVIEW"]. ''Chicago Stage Review'', May 10, 2010, Venus Zarris</ref><ref>[http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/music-arts/sarah-ruhl-epic-passion-play-passionate-life-death-jesus-christ-article-1.447939 "Sarah Ruhl's epic 'Passion Play' gets passionate about life and death of Jesus Christ"]. ''New York Daily News'', Joe Dziemianowicz. May 17, 2010,</ref> and ''Pike Street'' in 2015.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2015/11/18/theater/review-pike-st-where-one-woman-speaks-for-all.html?hpw&rref=theater&action=click&pgtype=Homepage&module=well-region&region=bottom-well&WT.nav=bottom-well&_r=0 "Review: ‘Pike St.,’ Where One Woman Speaks for All Pike St."]. ''New York Times'', by CHARLES ISHERWOOD NOV. 17, 2015.</ref><ref>[http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2015/11/23/team-player "Team Player"]. ''New York Magazine'', Hilton Als November 23, 2015.</ref>
In 2012, the theatre received funding from the [[National Endowment for the Arts]] to create a contemporary interpretation of Shakespeare's ''MacBeth''.<ref>[https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052702303459004577360011445835308 "Shakespeare for Everybody"]. ''Wall Street Journal'', By Pia Catton April 22, 2012</ref>
As well as performing traditional dramas, the Ensemble also commissions and stages new plays.<ref>[http://www.theatermania.com/off-broadway/news/nilaja-sun-pike-street-opening-night-photos_75003.html "Nilaja Sun Opens Pike St. at Abrons Arts Center"]. ''Theater Mania'', Nov 17, 2015</ref><ref>[https://www.americantheatre.org/2015/08/31/a-communitys-history-recovered-in-the-people-before-the-park/ "Keith Josef Adkins’s New Play Recovers ‘The People Before the Park’"]. ''American Theatre'', August 31, 2015. Amy Fuhrman</ref>
The Ensemble includes both professional and student actors.<ref>[http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2016/03/14/shakespeare-s-modern-lessons-for-new-york-schoolkids.html "Shakespeare’s Modern Lessons For New York Schoolkids"]. ''The Daily Beast'', 03.14.2016, by Robert Silverman</ref> In 2016, Epic Theatre Ensemble presented ''10467'', a fifty-minute play that discusses [[educational equity]] in New York City's public schools. .<ref>[http://www.villagevoice.com/news/nyc-high-schoolers-stand-up-for-their-educational-rights-on-stage-8419609 "NYC High Schoolers Stand Up for Their Educational Rights on Stage"]. Anita Abedain, ''The Village Voice'', March 22, 2016</ref> The play was written and performed by students of Epic's artistic and youth development program Epic NEXT ==References== {{reflist}}

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2016}} {{Use British English|date=December 2016}} {{Coord|50.709914|-3.513501|display=title|type:edu}} {{Infobox University |name = Exeter College of Art and Design |image = |motto = |established = 1854 |closed = 2000 |type = |staff = |head_label = |head = |principal = |undergrad = |postgrad = |doctoral = |city = [[Exeter]] |state = [[Devon]] |country = [[England]] |campus = |affiliations = |website = }} [[File:Exeter Phoenix - geograph.org.uk - 315723.jpg|thumb|right|The old School of Art building, now the Phoenix arts centre]] [[File:Exeter college of art.JPG|thumb|Exeter College of Art and Design Earl Richards Road North site 1980's]] '''Exeter College of Art and Design''' was an art college based in [[Exeter]], Devon. Founded in 1854, it amalgamated with what would become [[Plymouth University]] in 1989.
The main building was located at Earl Richards Road North Exeter from the 1970s with some facilities based at Barts until the early 1980s. Graphics was based on Gandy Street in the old School of Art buildings until it relocated to the main site in 1984. The Printmaking department was initially located at The Mint.<ref>{{cite web|title=Exeter Historic Buildings Trust|url=http://www.imaginarium.co.uk/ehbt/history2.htm|accessdate=11 April 2012}}</ref> The Art College offered higher education courses including Foundation, BA (Hons) and Combination courses with the University of Exeter as well as MA/Pg diplomas. Disciplines were, Fine Art Ceramics, Graphics, Painting, Printmaking, Photography, Sculpture and 4D (Film, Video, Sound).
The Priory Press was introduced by Alan Richards and Bernard Beard in association with The Bartholomew Print Workshop in the 1960s and produces limited edition handmade printed books.<ref>{{cite web|last=Maxted|first=Ian|title=Exeter Working Papers in British Book Trade History; 12 A history of the book in Devon|url=http://bookhistory.blogspot.co.uk/2007/01/devon-book-71.html|work=First published 2001|accessdate=7 April 2012}}</ref>
==History== The School of Art was founded in Exeter in 1854 as part of the [[Royal Albert Memorial Museum]] and promoted by [[Edward Bowring Stephens]] a local sculptor.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.exetermemories.co.uk/em/_people/stephens.php |title=Exeter Memories - E B Stephens |first= |last=Oxford National Biography |work=exetermemories.co.uk |year=2013 |accessdate=12 May 2013}}</ref> In 1858 decorative designer Kent Kingdon offered a £5 prize for a decorative design.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.exetermemories.co.uk/em/_people/kingdonkent.php |title=Exeter Memories - Kent Kingdon |first= |last= |work=exetermemories.co.uk |year=2013 |accessdate=11 May 2013}}</ref>
In 1951 The Exeter School of Art was renamed as the Exeter Central College of Art.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www1.plymouth.ac.uk/150/History/Pages/Art.aspx |title=Art history in Plymouth |first= |last= |work=www1.plymouth.ac.uk |year=2013 |accessdate=10 May 2013}}</ref>
[[Clifford Fishwick]] (1923–1997) was appointed Painting Master in 1947<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.theartroomtopsham.co.uk/portfolio.html |title=The Art Room: Portfolio - Devon Art Gallery in Topsham |first= |last= |work=theartroomtopsham.co.uk |year=2012 |quote=Martin Bentham |accessdate=12 May 2013}}</ref> and was principal of the college from 1958 to 1984 a skilled painter having trained at [[Art and Design Academy|Liverpool School of Art]], he was a friend of [[Peter Lanyon]] and exhibited regularly with the [[Penwith Society of Arts]].<ref>{{cite news |url= https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/obituary-clifford-fishwick-1285559.html |title=Obituary: Clifford Fishwick - People - News - The Independent |first= |last=A.Alvarez |work=[[The Independent]] |date= 28 January 1997|publisher=[[Independent News & Media|INM]] |location=[[London, UK|London]] |issn=0951-9467 |oclc=185201487 |accessdate=11 May 2013}}</ref> Fishwick is now regarded as an important, if underrated figure in post-war British painting and one of the better artists of the St Ives group.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.thisiscornwall.co.uk/Volume-exhibition-help-overlooked-figure-rightful/story-14145293-detail/story.html#axzz2StIo1SWO |title=Volume and exhibition help put overlooked figure in rightful place | This is Cornwall |first= |last= |work=thisiscornwall.co.uk |year=2013 |accessdate=11 May 2013}}</ref>
In 1966 students print work was featured in an exhibition entitled "An Approach to Printmaking in Exeter" at The [[Whitechapel Gallery]], London. In 1973 the College was renamed again as Exeter College of Art and Design and a new building opened at Earl Richards Road North on the outskirts of Exeter.
In 1976 painting tutor John Butler set up The [[Spacex (art gallery)]] which became a registered educational charity in 1990.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.artbiogs.co.uk/2/galleries/spacex-gallery |title=Spacex Gallery | Artist Biographies |first= |last= |work=artbiogs.co.uk |year=2013 |accessdate=12 May 2013}}</ref>
The college amalgamated with Polytechnic South West based in Plymouth in 1989 and in 2007 the facilities moved permanently to the Plymouth Campus. In 2011 planning permission was granted to demolish and redevelop the site to provide 39 dwellings with parking and landscaping.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://pub.exeter.gov.uk/scripts/acolnet/planning/AcolnetCGI.gov?ACTION=UNWRAP&RIPNAME=Root.PgeDocs&TheSystemkey=66089 |title=Planning Pages |first= |last= |work=pub.exeter.gov.uk |year=2013 |accessdate=12 May 2013}}</ref>

{{Infobox Painting | image_file=File:Paul Gauguin - Fatata te Miti (By the Sea) - Google Art Project.jpg | image_size =350px | title=Fatata te Miti | artist=[[Paul Gauguin]] | year=1892 | catalogue= W 463 | type=[[Oil paint]] on [[canvas]] | dimensions = {{convert|68|x|92|cm|in}} | city=[[Washington DC]] | museum=[[National Gallery of Art]] }}
'''''Fatata te Miti''''' is an 1892 [[oil painting]] by [[France|French]] artist [[Paul Gauguin]], located in the [[National Gallery of Art]], in [[Washington, DC]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wga.hu/html_m/g/gauguin/04/tahiti23.html|title=By the Sea (Fatata te Miti)|publisher=Web Gallery of Art|accessdate=6 October 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://topics.nytimes.com/top/reference/timestopics/people/g/paul_gauguin/index.html|title=Paul Gauguin New York Times|publisher=New York Times|accessdate=6 October 2014}}</ref>
==Painting== [[File:Gauguin Arearea no varua ino.jpg|thumb|left|''Arearea no varua ino (The Amusement of the Evil Spirit)'', 1894, [[Ny Carlsberg Glyptotek]]]] [[File:Paul Gauguin - Parau na te Varua ino (1892).jpg|thumb|left|''Parau na te Varua ino (Words of the Devil)'', 1892, [[National Gallery of Art | National Gallery of Art Washington]]]] [[File:Paul Gauguin - "In the waves" or "Ondine" - 1889.jpg|thumb|''In the wave'' or ''Ondine'', 1889, [[Cleveland Museum of Art]]]] Gauguin painted ''Fatata te miti (By the Sea)'' in 1892 during his first trip to [[Tahiti]]. Like ''[[Vahine no te vi | Vahine no te vi (Woman of the Mango)]]'' (W 449) painted at the same time, it is an example of the relatively few straightforward genre scenes that Gauguin painted immediately after setting up his studio in a native bamboo hut at Mataiea, [[Papeari]].<ref name= Stuckey/> Nevertheless, as [[Nancy Mowll Mathews]], Gauguin's biographer, points out, neither represents what he actually ''saw''; the paintings transforming the mundane and ordinary into an exoticized view of the island's life.<ref name= Mathews>Mathews pp. 171-2</ref> A pendant painting ''[[Arearea no varua ino]] (The Amusement of the Evil Spirit)'' (W 514), executed shortly after Gauguin had returned to Paris, appears to share the same setting and demonstrates how he moved on from simple genre painting, introducing [[symbolism (arts) | symbolist]] elements. The same tree, dividing the painting into two distinct zones, can be seen in ''[[Parau na te Varua ino]] (Words of the Devil)'' (W 458).<ref name= Stuckey/>
The painting depicts two Tahitian women, seen from behind, jumping into the sea. There is a [[fisherman]] in the background, fishing with a spear. The painting epitomizes the [[Romanticism |romantic]] view of Tahitians made famous by [[Pierre Loti | Pierre Loti's]] ''[[Le Mariage de Loti]]''. In that novel, Loti described his Tahitian bride's pursuits as extremely simple, "reverie, bathing, above all bathing".<ref>Stuckey p.276 quoting Loti ch. VIII</ref> The women in the painting bathe naked, removing their ''[[pareo]]s'', apparently unbothered by the presence of the fisherman nearby. This is an image of the uninhibited tropical paradise Gauguin had hoped to find, although the reality was that Polynesian culture had been transformed by western [[missionaries]] and [[colonialism]] as they imposed their own values and religion on the people living in the islands.<ref name= Stuckey>Stuckey pp. 276-7</ref><ref name= NGA>{{cite web|title=Fatata te Miti (By the Sea)|url=https://www.nga.gov/collection/gallery/gg82/gg82-46624.html|website=nga.gov|publisher=[[National Gallery of Art]]}}</ref>
The theme of nymphs frolicking in the waves was a tradition of the [[Golden Age]] repeatedly represented by artists such as Titian and Courbet through to Gauguin's own contemporary Degas. Gauguin was fascinated by the theme, first taking it up in 1885 with his ''[[Women Bathing]]'' (W 167). He returned to it with his 1889 ''[[Ondine (Gauguin) | Ondine]]'' (W 336), his signature painting at the [[The Volpini Exhibition, 1889 | Volpini Exhibition]].<ref name = Stuckey/>
Gauguin uses intense tropical colors to convey sensual delight.<ref name = NGA/> For example, he uses pinks and purples for the sand, although in reality the beaches were a drab volcanic brown.<ref name= Mathews/> The technique employed here of applying pure (unmixed) color in bold and flat shapes delineated by dark counters is one he developed in [[Pont-Aven School | Brittany]], dubbed ''[[cloisonnism]]''.<ref name= Stuckey/> Eisenman remarks that in this and similar paintings, Gauguin placed jigsaw puzzles shapes of complementary and adjacent shades side by side as binaries to suggest a coloristic liminal intermediary, reflecting Gauguin's spiritual belief that binaries such as the moral and physical universe were reconcilable.<ref>Eisenman p. 130</ref> To heighten the luminosity and enhance their jewellike effect, Gauguin applied a thin layer of clear wax to the surface of his early Tahitian paintings.<ref name= Stuckey/>
The painting was previously owned by [[Chester Dale]], who left his collection to the National Gallery of Art, Washington, D.C. in 1962.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://arthistory.about.com/od/from_exhibitions/ig/chester_dale_collection/cdc_nga_2010-11_35.htm|title=From Impressionism to Modernism: The Chester Dale Collection|publisher=About Education|accessdate=6 October 2014}}</ref>
==First Tahitian period== Looking for a society more elemental and simple than that in France, Gauguin auctioned thirty of his paintings and used the money to travel to Tahiti. This first visit lasted from 1891 to 1893. His book ''{{Interlanguage link multi|Noa Noa|ca}}'' was written in the style of a travel journal and was originally meant to provide a context for his 1893 Paris exhibition. Gauguin first used the words "Noa Noa" reporting the words the Tahitians themselves used for the scent of Tahitian women: ''"Téiné merahi '''noa noa''' "'' meaning ''"(now) very '''fragrant'''"''.<ref>{{cite web|title=Paul Gauguin's Noa Noa|url=http://www.clevelandart.org/research/in-the-library/collection-in-focus/paul-gauguins-noa-noa|website=clevelandart.org|publisher=[[Cleveland Museum of Art]]|quote=A mingled perfume, half animal, half vegetable emanated from them; the perfume of their blood and of the gardenias—tiaré—which they wore in their hair. "Téiné merahi noa noa (now very fragrant)," they said.}}</ref> The substantive ''Fenua'' ("land" or "island") is understood in the title of his book, so the correct translation is "The Fragrant Isle". Also implied is the Tahitian term for "Paradise" - ''Rohutu noanoa''.<ref>Danielsson (1965) p. 158</ref> In the event his book remained unpublished until 1901, although extracts were published in ''[[La Revue Blanche]]'' in 1897.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.clevelandart.org/research/in-the-library/collection-in-focus/paul-gauguins-noa-noa|title=Paul Gauguin's Noa Noa|publisher=www.clevelandart.org|accessdate=}}</ref><ref>Mathews p. 247</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Noa Noa|url=http://data.bnf.fr/12079829/paul_gauguin_noa_noa/|website=bnf.fr|publisher=[[Bibliothèque nationale de France]]}}</ref> The first European exhibition of Gauguin's work took place in March 1893 in Copenhagen, when he was able to take up the offer of a visiting sea captain and send out eight selected paintings.<ref>Danielsson p. 125</ref>
<gallery mode="packed" heights="110px" caption="Paintings from Gauguin's first Tahitian period selected for his Copenhagen exhibition"> File:Parau Parau Whispered Words by Paul Gauguin 1892.jpeg File:Eh quoi! Tu es jaloux? by Paul Gauguin.jpg File:Paul Gauguin- Manao tupapau (The Spirit of the Dead Keep Watch).JPG File:Paul Gauguin 049.jpg File:Paul Gauguin 045.jpg File:Paul Gauguin 027.jpg File:Paul Gauguin - I Raro Te Oviri (Under the Pandanus) - Google Art Project.jpg File:Gauguin Te fare.jpg </gallery>

{{See also|List of genres| List of genres#Film and television formats and genres}} {{multiple issues| {{Original research|date= July 2017}} {{Refimprove|date= July 2017}} }} [[File:Clint Eastwood - 1960s.JPG|thumb|180px|Subash Kumar<ref>{{Citation|title=SUBASH KUMAR v. PRINCIPAL OFFICER|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1017/cbo9781316152195.039|work=International Law Reports|pages=578–584|editor-last=Lauterpacht|editor-first=E.|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=9781316152195|access-date=2018-12-02|editor2-last=Greenwood|editor2-first=C. J.}}</ref>[[Western film]]s are those "set in the [[American West]] that embod[y] the spirit, the struggle and the demise of the [[Frontier Thesis| new frontier]]."<ref>{{cite web| title= America's 10 Greatest Films in 10 Classic Genres | url= http://www.afi.com/10top10/ | publisher= [[American Film Institute]] | accessdate= 2010-06-06 | quote = AFI defines 'western' as a genre of films set in the American West that embodies the spirit, the struggle and the demise of the new frontier.}}</ref> Pictured: [[Clint Eastwood]] in the Western film ''[[A Fistful of Dollars]]'' (1964).|alt=]] A '''film genre''' is a motion-picture category based (for example) on similarities either in the [[narrative| narrative elements]] or in the emotional response to the film (namely: serious, comic, etc.).{{cn|date=October 2018}} Most theories of film genre are borrowed from [[literary genre | literary-genre]] criticism. Each film genre is associated{{by whom?|date=October 2018}} with "conventions, iconography, [[Movie setting | setting]]s, narratives, [[stock character|characters]] and actors". <ref> Compare: {{cite book | last1 = Grant | first1 = Barry Keith | author-link1 = Barry Keith Grant | title = Film Genre: From Iconography to Ideology | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=tCQOwvI9vsAC | series = Short cuts | volume = 33 | edition = reprint | location = London | publisher = Wallflower Press | publication-date = 2007 | page = 2 | isbn = 9781904764793 | access-date = 2018-10-13 | quote = [...] the various elements of genre films, including conventions, iconography, settings, narratives, characters and actors. }} </ref> Standard genre characters vary according to the film genre; for [[film noir]], standard characters are the [[femme fatale]]<ref>Grant, Barry Keith. ''Film Genre: From Iconography to Ideology.'' Wallflower Press, 2007. p. 17</ref> and the [[Hardboiled detective | "hardboiled" detective]]; a Western film may portray the schoolmarm and the gunfighter. Some actors acquire a reputation linked to a single genre, such as [[John Wayne]] (the Western) or [[Fred Astaire]] (the musical).<ref>Grant, Barry Keith. ''Film Genre: From Iconography to Ideology.'' Wallflower Press, 2007. p. 18</ref> A film's genre will influence the use of [[filmmaking]] styles and techniques, such as the use of [[flashback (narrative)| flashback]]s and low-key lighting in film noir, tight framing in horror films, fonts that look like rough-hewn logs for the titles of Western films, or the "scrawled" title-font and credits of ''[[Seven (1995 film)|Se7en]]'' (1995), a film about a serial killer.<ref>Grant, Barry Keith. ''Film Genre: From Iconography to Ideology.'' Wallflower Press, 2007. p. 11</ref> As well, genres have associated [[film scoring | film-scoring]] conventions, such as lush string orchestras for romantic [[melodrama]]s or electronic music for [[science-fiction film]]s.<ref>Grant, Barry Keith. ''Film Genre: From Iconography to Ideology.'' Wallflower Press, 2007. p. 11</ref>
The basic [[genre]]s<ref>[[Judith Butler]] and genre theory</ref> include [[fiction]] and [[documentary]], from which subgenres have emerged, such as [[docufiction]] and [[docudrama]]. Other examples of subgenres include the courtroom- and trial-focused [[Drama (modern genre)|drama]] known as the [[legal drama]], which is a subtype of drama. Types of fiction which may seem unrelated can also be combined to form hybrid subgenres, such as the melding of horror and comedy in the [[The Evil Dead (franchise) | ''Evil Dead'']] films. Other popular combinations include the [[romantic comedy]] and the [[action comedy]] film. [[Alan Williams (disambiguation) | Alan Williams]] distinguishes three main genre categories: [[Narrative film | narrative]], [[Avant-garde film | avant-garde]] and documentary.<ref> Compare: {{cite book | last1 = Hayward | first1 = Susan | orig-year = 1996 | title = Cinema Studies: The Key Concepts | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=gp4xDwAAQBAJ | series = Routledge Key Guides | edition = 5 | location = Abingdon | publisher = Routledge | publication-date = 2017 | page = | isbn = 9781317214793 | access-date = 2018-10-13 | quote = Alan Williams (quoted in Neale, 1990: 62) speaks of 'principal genres' to refer to what he sees as the three main categories of film: '''narrative''' film, '''avant-garde''' film and '''documentary'''. He reserves the term ''sub-genres'' to refer to what we term ''film genres''. }} </ref> [[Genre film | Genre movies]] are "commercial feature films which, through repetition and variation, tell familiar stories with familiar characters and familiar situations".<ref>Grant, Barry Keith. ''Film Genre: From Iconography to Ideology.'' Wallflower Press, 2007. p. 1</ref> Genre affects how films are broadcast on television, advertised, and organized in [[video rental store]]s.<ref>Grant, Barry Keith. ''Film Genre: From Iconography to Ideology.'' Wallflower Press, 2007. p. 1</ref>
Films can also be classified by the setting, theme, topic, mood, format, target audience or budget. The setting is the environment where the story and action take place (e.g., a [[war film]], a [[Western film]], or a [[space opera|space-opera film]]). The theme or topic refers to the issues or concepts that the film revolves around (e.g., [[science-fiction film]], [[sports film]], or [[crime film]]). The mood is the emotional tone of the film (e.g., [[comedy film]], [[horror film]], or tearjerker film). Format refers to the way the film was shot (e.g., [[35 mm]], [[16 mm]] or [[8 mm film|8 mm]]) or the manner of presentation (e.g.: [[anamorphic widescreen]]). Additional ways of categorizing film genres may involve the target audience (e.g., [[children's film]], [[teen film]] or [[women's film]]) or by type of [[film production | production]] (e.g., [[B movie]], [[Blockbuster (entertainment) |big-budget blockbuster]] or [[low-budget film]]). ''Genre'' does not just refer to the type of film or its category; spectator expectations about a film, and institutional discourses that create generic structures also play a key role.<ref name="autogenerated185"> Hayward, Susan. "Genre/Sub-genre" in ''Cinema Studies: The Key Concepts'' (Third Edition). Routledge, 2006. p. 185-192 </ref> Genres are not fixed; they change and evolve over time, and some genres may largely disappear (for example, the melodrama).<ref name="autogenerated185"/>
==History== The term "genre" was used to organize films according to type since the earliest days of cinema.<ref name="autogenerated185"/> By the 1950s, [[André Bazin]] was discussing the concept of "genre" by using the [[Western (genre)#Film|Western film]] as an example; during this era, there was a debate over [[auteur theory]] versus genre.<ref name="autogenerated185"/> In the late 1960s, the concept of genre became a significant part of [[film theory]].<ref name="autogenerated185"/><ref name="autogenerated185"/>
Film genres draw on genres from other forms; Western novels existed before the Western film, and [[musical theatre]] existed before film musicals were made.<ref>Grant, Barry Keith. ''Film Genre: From Iconography to Ideology.'' Wallflower Press, 2007. p. 4</ref> The perceived genre of a film can change over time; for example, ''[[The Great Train Robbery (1903 film)|The Great Train Robbery]]'' (1903) is seen in the 2010s as a key early Western film, but when it was released, it was seen as related to the "then-popular genres of the chase film, the railroad film and the crime film".<ref>Grant, Barry Keith. ''Film Genre: From Iconography to Ideology.'' Wallflower Press, 2007. p. 6</ref> A key reason that the early Hollywood industrial system from the 1920s to the 1950s favoured genre films is that in "Hollywood's industrial mode of production, genre movies are dependable products" to market to audiences, they are easy to produce and it is easy for audiences to understand a genre film.<ref>Grant, Barry Keith. ''Film Genre: From Iconography to Ideology.'' Wallflower Press, 2007. p. 7-8</ref> In the 1920s to 1950s, genre films had clear conventions and iconography, such as the heavy coats worn by gangsters in films like ''[[Little Caesar (film)|Little Caesar]]'' (1931).<ref>Grant, Barry Keith. ''Film Genre: From Iconography to Ideology.'' Wallflower Press, 2007. p. 8</ref> The conventions in genre films enable filmmakers to create them in an industrial, assembly line fashion, an approach which can be seen in the [[James Bond]] spy films, which all use a formula of "lots of action, fancy gadgets, beautiful woman and colourful villains", even though the actors, directors and screenwriters changed. <ref>Grant, Barry Keith. ''Film Genre: From Iconography to Ideology.'' Wallflower Press, 2007. p. 8</ref>
==Pure and hybrid genres== Films are rarely purely from one genre, which is in keeping with the cinema's diverse and derivative origins, it being a blend of "vaudeville, music-hall, theatre, photography" and novels.<ref name="autogenerated185"/> American film historian [[Janet Staiger]] states that the genre of a film can be defined in four ways. The "idealist method" judges films by predetermined standards. The "empirical method" identifies the genre of a film by comparing it to a list of films already deemed to fall within a certain genre. The [[A priori knowledge|apriori]] method uses common generic elements which are identified in advance. The "social conventions" method of identifying the genre of a film is based on the accepted cultural consensus within society.<ref name="Grant"/> Martin Loop contends that [[Cinema of the United States|Hollywood]] films are not pure genres because most Hollywood movies blend the love-oriented plot of the romance genre with other genres.<ref name="Grant">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tCQOwvI9vsAC|title=Film Genre: From Iconography to Ideology|last=Grant|first=Barry Keith|date=2007|publisher=Wallflower Press|isbn=9781904764793|language=en}}</ref> Jim Colins claims that since the 1980s, Hollywood films have been influenced by the trend towards "ironic hybridization", in which directors combine elements from different genres, as with the Western/science fiction mix in ''[[Back to the Future Part III]]''.<ref name="Grant"/>
Many films cross into multiple genres. Susan Hayward states that spy films often cross genre boundaries with thriller films. <ref name="autogenerated185"/> Some genre films take genre elements from one genre and place them into the conventions of a second genre, such as with ''[[The Band Wagon]]'' (1953), which adds film noir and detective film elements into "The Girl Hunt" ballet.<ref>Grant, Barry Keith. ''Film Genre: From Iconography to Ideology.'' Wallflower Press, 2007. p. 8</ref> In the 1970s [[New Hollywood]] era, there was so much parodying of genres that it can be hard to assign genres to some films from this era, such as [[Mel Brooks]]' comedy-Western ''[[Blazing Saddles]]'' (1974) or the private eye parody ''[[The Long Goodbye (film)|The Long Goodbye]]'' (1973). <ref name="autogenerated185"/> Other films from this era bend genres so much that it is challenging to put them in a genre category, such as [[Roman Polanski]]'s ''[[Chinatown (1974 film)|Chinatown]]'' (1974) and [[William Friedkin]]'s ''[[The French Connection (film)|The French Connection]]'' (1971).<ref name="autogenerated185"/>
[[Film theory|Film theorist]] [[Robert Stam]] challenged whether genres really exist, or whether they are merely made up by critics. Stam has questioned whether "genres [are] really 'out there' in the world or are they really the construction of analysts?". As well, he has asked whether there is a "... finite taxonomy of genres or are they in principle infinite?" and whether genres are "...timeless essences ephemeral, time-bound entities? Are genres culture-bound or trans-cultural?" Stam has also asked whether genre analysis should aim at being descriptive or prescriptive. While some genres are based on story content (the [[war film]]), other are borrowed from literature ([[Comedic genres|comedy]], [[melodrama]]) or from other media (the [[musical film|musical]]). Some are performer-based ([[Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers]] films) or budget-based ([[Blockbuster (entertainment)|blockbusters]], [[low budget film]]), while others are based on artistic status (the [[art film]]), racial identity ([[Race films]]), location (the [[Western (genre)|Western]]), or sexual orientation ([[Queer cinema]]).<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mzRXmmpFgZEC|title=Film Theory: An Anthology|last=Stam|first=Robert|date=2000-02-21|publisher=Wiley|isbn=9780631206545|language=en}}</ref>
== Audience expectations == Many genres have built-in [[audience]]s and corresponding publications that support them, such as magazines and websites. For example, horror films have a well-established fanbase that reads horror magazines such as ''[[Fangoria]]''. Films that are difficult to categorize into a genre are often less successful. As such, film genres are also useful in the areas of marketing, [[film criticism]] and the analysis of [[consumption (economics)|consumption]]. Hollywood story consultant [[John Truby]] states that "...you have to know how to transcend the forms [genres] so you can give the audience a sense of originality and surprise."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.writersstore.com/whats-my-genre/|title=What's My Genre?|last=Truby|first=John|authorlink=John Truby|date=|website=Writers Store|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=2007-07-31}}</ref>
Some [[screenwriter]]s use genre as a means of determining what kind of plot or content to put into a screenplay. They may study films of specific genres to find examples. This is a way that some screenwriters are able to copy elements of successful movies and pass them off in a new [[screenplay]]. It is likely that such screenplays fall short in originality. As Truby says, "Writers know enough to write a genre script but they haven’t twisted the story beats of that genre in such a way that it gives an original face to it".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.scriptmag.com/earticles/earticle.htm|title=Interview: John Truby on Screenwriting and Breaking In|last=Ward|first=Lewis|date=|work=Script Magazine|dead-url=yes|accessdate=2007-07-31|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070702182835/http://www.scriptmag.com/earticles/earticle.htm|archivedate=2007-07-02}}</ref>
Cinema technologies are associated with genres. Huge widescreens helped Western films to create an expansive setting of the open plains and desert. Science fiction and fantasy films are associated with special effects, notably computer generated imagery (e.g., the Harry Potter films).<ref name="autogenerated185"/>
== Grouping vs. genre == There are other methods of dividing films into groups besides genre. For example, [[auteur]] critics group films according to their auteur-directors. Production attributes, such as the [[low-budget film]], can also be considered a grouping. Some groupings may be casually described as genres although the definition is questionable.{{Citation needed|date=March 2009}} For example, while [[independent film]]s are sometimes discussed as if they are a genre in-and-of themselves, independent productions can belong to any genre. Similarly, while [[art film]]s are referred to as a genre by film scholar [[David Bordwell]], who states that "art cinema itself is a [film] genre, with its own distinct conventions",<ref name="Grant" /> an art film can be in a number of genres (e.g., [[drama]], [[experimental film]], [[black comedy]], etc.).
==Categorization== [[File:All Quiet on the Western Front (1930 film) poster.jpg|thumb|upright=0.8|[[War film]] or [[Anti-war film|anti-war movie]]: [[Lewis Milestone]]'s ''[[All Quiet on the Western Front (1930 film)|All Quiet on the Western Front]]'', 1930]] Because genres are easier to recognize than to define, academics agree they cannot be identified in a rigid way.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=FUNBpwAACAAJ|title=Film Art: An Introduction|last=Thompson|first=Kristin|last2=Bordwell|first2=David|date=2012-07-06|publisher=McGraw-Hill Education|year=|isbn=9780073535104|location=|pages=|language=en}}</ref> Furthermore, different countries and cultures define genres in different ways. A typical example are war movies. In US, they are mostly related to the two World Wars whereas, in other countries, movies related to wars in other historical periods are considered ''war movies''.
Film genres may appear to be readily categorizable from the setting of the film. Nevertheless, films with the same settings can be very different, due to the use of different themes or moods. For example, while both ''[[Midway (1976 film)|The Battle of Midway]]'' and ''[[All Quiet on the Western Front (1930 film)|All Quiet on the Western Front]]'' are set in a [[war]]time context and might be classified as belonging to the [[war film]] genre, the first examines the themes of honor, sacrifice, and valour, and the second is an [[anti-war film]] which emphasizes the pain and horror of war. While there is an argument that [[film noir]] movies could be deemed to be set in an urban setting, in cheap hotels and underworld bars, many classic noirs take place mainly in small towns, suburbia, rural areas, or on the open road.<ref name="google">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Dxis1i4jxVwC|title=Architecture and Film|last=Lamster|first=Mark|date=2000|publisher=Princeton Architectural Press|isbn=9781568982076|page=217}}</ref>
The editors of filmsite.org argue that animation, [[pornographic film]], documentary film, [[silent film]] and so on are non-genre-based film categories.<ref name="filmsite">{{cite web|url=http://www.filmsite.org/genres2.html |title=Other Major Film Categories |publisher=filmsite.org|accessdate=2015-03-14}}</ref>
[[Linda Williams (film critic)|Linda Williams]] argues that horror, melodrama, and pornography all fall into the category of "body genres" since they are each designed to elicit physical reactions on the part of viewers. Horror is designed to elicit spine-chilling, white-knuckled, eye-bulging terror; melodramas are designed to make viewers cry after seeing the misfortunes of the onscreen characters; and pornography is designed to elicit sexual arousal.{{citation needed|date=March 2015}} This approach can be extended: comedies make people laugh, tear-jerkers make people cry, feel-good films lift people's spirits and inspiration films provide hope for viewers.
A genre movie is a film that follows some or all of the conventions of a particular genre, whether or not it was intentional when the movie was produced.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RbKuuBqBWg8C|title=Journalists in Film: Heroes and Villains|last=McNair|first=Brian|date=2010|publisher=Edinburgh University Press|isbn=9780748634477|language=en}}</ref>
==Film and history== In order to understand the creation and context of each film genre, we must look at its popularity in the context of its place in history. For example, the 1970s [[Blaxploitation]] films have been called an attempt to "undermine the rise of Afro-American's Black consciousness movement" of that era.<ref name="autogenerated185"/> In William Park's analysis of film noir, he states that we must view and interpret film for its message with the context of history within our minds; he states that this is how film can truly be understood by its audience.<ref name="What is Film Noir?"> Park W. What Is Film Noir? [e-book]. Lanham, Md: Bucknell University Press; 2011. Available from: eBook Collection (EBSCOhost), Ipswich, MA. Accessed November 19, 2017.</ref> Film genres such as [[film noir]] and [[Western film]] reflect values of the time period. While film noir combines German expressionist filming strategies with post World War II ideals; Western films focused on the ideal of the early 20th century. Films such as the [[Musical film|musical]] were created as a form of entertainment during the [[Great Depression]] allowing its viewers an escape during tough times. So when watching and analyzing film genres we must remember to remember its true intentions aside from its entertainment value.
Over time, a genre can change through stages: the classic genre era; the parody of the classics; the period where filmmakers deny that their films are part of a certain genre; and finally a critique of the entire genre.<ref name="autogenerated185"/> This pattern can be seen with the Western film. In the earliest, classic Westerns, there was a clear hero who protected society from lawless villains who lived in the wilderness and came into civilization to commit crimes.<ref name="autogenerated185"/> However, in [[revisionist Western]]s of the 1970s, the protagonist becomes an [[anti-hero]] who lives in the wilderness to get away from a civilization that is depicted as corrupt, with the villains now integrated into society. Another example of a genre changing over time is the popularity of the [[neo-noir]] films in the early 2000s (''[[Mulholland Drive]]'' (2001), ''[[The Man Who Wasn't There (2001 film)|The Man Who Wasn't There]]'' (2001) and ''[[Far From Heaven]]'' (2002); are these film noir parodies, a repetition of noir genre tropes, or a re-examination of the noir genre?<ref name="autogenerated185"/>
This is also important to remember when looking at films in the future. As viewers watch a film they are conscious of societal influence with the film itself. In order to understand it's true intentions, we must identify its intended audience and what narrative of our current society, as well as it comments to the past in relation with today's society. This enables viewers to understand the evolution of film genres as time and history morphs or views and ideals of the entertainment industry.

{{Use British English|date=July 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} {{Infobox person |name = Gabby Logan |image = Gabby Logan cropped.jpg |birthname = Gabrielle Nicole Yorath |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1973|4|24|df=y}} |birth_place = [[Leeds]], [[West Riding of Yorkshire]], [[England]] |death_date = |death_place = |nationality = British |known_for = [[Gymnastics|Gymnast]], television presenter |education = [[Cardinal Heenan Roman Catholic High School]]
[[Notre Dame Catholic Sixth Form College]] |alma_mater = [[College of St Hild and St Bede]], [[Durham University]] |employer = [[BBC]] (current)
[[ITV (TV network)|ITV]] (current)
[[Channel 5 (UK)|Channel 5]] (former) |occupation = Television and radio presenter |years_active = 1995–present |residence = [[Kew]], London, England |spouse = [[Kenny Logan]] (m. 2001) |children = 2 |parents = [[Terry Yorath|Terry]] and Christine Yorath |website = [http://www.gabbylogan.com/ Official website] | module = {{Infobox sportsperson | embed =yes | country = [[Wales]] | sport = [[Gymnastics]] | event = {{ubl| '''[[1990 Commonwealth Games]]''': [[Gymnastics at the 1990 Commonwealth Games|Rhythmic Individual All-Around]]}} }} }} '''Gabrielle Nicole "Gabby" Logan''' (née '''Yorath'''; born 24 April 1973) is a British presenter and a former [[Welsh Gymnastics|Welsh international gymnast]] who is best known for her presenting roles with [[BBC Sport]] and [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]].{{cite news |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/sport/rugby_union/article5941115.ece |title=It's time for the English to play the hatred game with Scots |newspaper=[[The Times]] |date=20 March 2009 |accessdate=28 December 2009 |first=Gabby |last=Logan }} Logan hosted ''[[Final Score]]'' for [[BBC Sport]] from 2009 until 2013. She has also presented a variety of live sports events for the [[BBC]], including a revived episode of ''[[Superstars]]'' in December 2012 and the [[London Marathon]] since 2015.{{cite web |url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/tv/news/a438072/superstars-to-return-for-olympic-special-at-christmas.html |title=''Superstars'' to return for Olympic special at Christmas |website=[[Digital Spy]] |date=14 November 2012 |accessdate=25 January 2014 }} Since 2013, she has co-hosted ''[[BBC Sports Personality of the Year|Sports Personality of the Year]]'' for the [[BBC]] and she presented the second series of ''[[The Edge (game show)|The Edge]]'' in 2015. ==Early life== Logan was born in [[Leeds]] in the [[West Riding of Yorkshire]] to former [[Wales national football team|Welsh international footballer]] and manager [[Terry Yorath]] and his wife Christine when Yorath was playing for [[Leeds United F.C.|Leeds United]].{{cite magazine |title=Gabby Logan: Why Leeds will always have a special place in my heart |url=http://www.yorkshirelife.co.uk/people/celebrity-interviews/gabby_logan_why_leeds_will_always_hold_a_special_place_in_my_heart_1_1571450 |magazine=Yorkshire Life |accessdate=21 August 2017}} Due to her father's career, Logan had to move around much in her youth, as her father played for a number of British teams as well as the Canadian team [[Vancouver Whitecaps (NASL)|Vancouver Whitecaps]].{{cite news |url=http://observer.guardian.co.uk/osm/story/0,,708320,00.html |title=Angelic Host |first=Amy |last=Raphael |newspaper=[[The Observer]] |date=5 May 2002 |accessdate=27 December 2009 |location=London}} She attended [[Bishop Ullathorne RC School]] in [[Coventry]], [[Cardinal Heenan Roman Catholic High School|Cardinal Heenan High School]] and [[Notre Dame Sixth Form College]] in Leeds and read Law at the [[College of St Hild and St Bede]], [[Durham University]]. Logan played [[netball]] at school and at university and also competed at [[high jump]], but the peak of her sporting career was when she placed 11th in [[rhythmic gymnastics]] representing Wales at the [[1990 Commonwealth Games]] in [[Auckland]].{{cite news |url=http://observer.guardian.co.uk/omm/recorddoctor/story/0,,1395887,00.html |newspaper=The Observer |location=London |title=The Record Doctor: Gabby Logan |accessdate=3 May 2010}} She had to retire from gymnastics aged 17 due to [[sciatica]]. Logan became interested in football during her regular attendances at her father's matches, to which her mother went out of a "sense of duty". On 11 May 1985, she was in the crowd at [[Valley Parade]] when the [[Bradford City stadium fire]] happened. She, along with her brother and sister, had left the stand only moments before the fire took hold and watched the disaster taking place.{{cite news |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/sport/football/article1131387.ece |title= Day that will live with me forever |website=[[The Times Online]] |date=12 May 2003 |accessdate=29 April 2009 |location=London |first=Gabby |last=Logan}} Logan's debut TV appearance was when she was chosen as the Leeds Rose for the 1991 [[Rose of Tralee (festival)|Rose of Tralee]] competition.{{cite web |title=Leeds Rose Gabby Logan Wants To Be A TV Presenter 1991 |url=http://www.rte.ie/archives/2016/0811/808549-gabby-logan-leeds-rose/ |website=[[RTE]] |accessdate=21 August 2017}}{{Dead Link|date=August 2017}}{{cite web |url=http://www.thegatheringireland.com/Latest-Stories/Blog/March-2013/13-fun-facts-about-the-Rose-of-Tralee |title=13 fun facts about the Rose of Tralee |website=The Gathering |date=3 February 2013 |accessdate=5 August 2013|deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130805110129/http://www.thegatheringireland.com/Latest-Stories/Blog/March-2013/13-fun-facts-about-the-Rose-of-Tralee |archivedate=5 August 2013 |df=dmy-all}} Logan [[running|runs]] and plays golf and is a supporter of [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]]{{cite news |url=http://icnewcastle.icnetwork.co.uk/0300entertainment/onthebox/2002/08/22/gabby-has-her-eye-firmly-on-the-ball-50081-12136075/ |title=Gabby has her eye firmly on the ball |newspaper=[[Newcastle Evening Chronicle]] |date=22 August 2002 |accessdate=20 August 2008}} stretching back to her time at [[Durham University]], where her then boyfriend was a childhood fan. She remembers her first match as Newcastle's 1–0 [[Premier League]] victory over [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] on 25 August 1993{{cite news |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/sport/columnists/article5568992.ece |title=Dear Joe Kinnear, let me put it in black and white |website=Times Online |first=Gabby |last=Logan |date=23 January 2009 |accessdate=31 May 2009 |location=London}} and made visits by air or rail to [[St. James' Park, Newcastle|St. James' Park]] throughout the 1990s and early 2000s, including Newcastle's 5–0 win over [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] on 20 October 1996. ==Early career== After university, Logan began presenting on [[Metro Radio]] in [[Newcastle upon Tyne|Newcastle]], from where she was offered a job as a presenter on [[Sky Sports]] in 1996. She worked there until 1998, when she joined the [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]] TV network. ==Television== ===ITV=== Logan's career came to notice when she fronted ''[[On the Ball (ITV television show)|On the Ball]]''. Logan was one of a small number of female sports presenters to have made the transition to terrestrial television. After [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]] lost the terrestrial rights to the [[Premier League]], she presented their [[UEFA Champions League]] coverage, including the [[2005 UEFA Champions League Final|2005]] and [[2006 UEFA Champions League Final|2006 finals]], between [[A.C. Milan]] and [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]], and [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] and [[FC Barcelona|Barcelona]], respectively. Logan left ITV for [[BBC Sport]] in December 2006, In 2003, she reported on the [[2003 Rugby World Cup|Rugby World Cup]]. Also that year, Logan presented a programme called ''Britain's Brilliant Prodigies'' featuring a young [[Jessie J]]. Logan stepped in for [[Melanie Sykes]] on 6 July 2004 when she went on maternity leave partway through the third series of game show ''[[The Vault (game show)|The Vault]]''. Gabby co-hosted the celebrity diving show ''[[Splash! (UK TV series)|Splash!]]'' on [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]], alongside [[Vernon Kay]] and Olympic diver [[Tom Daley]] from 2013 until 2014. In 2015, Logan returned to [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]] for reality series ''[[Flockstars]]''. In an interview with [[Radio Times]] in November 2016, Logan admitted that ''[[Flockstars]]'' was her "biggest disappointment".{{cite web |url=http://www.digitalspy.com/tv/news/a815369/gabby-logan-says-flockstars-was-disappointment-because-rich-content-was-cut/ |title=Gabby Logan admits Flockstars was a disappointment |date=28 November 2016 |website=Digital Spy |accessdate=7 December 2017}} ===BBC=== Logan started presenting for [[BBC Sport]] on 27 January 2007, presenting coverage of the [[FA Cup]] fourth round tie between [[Luton Town F.C.|Luton Town]] and [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]]. She continues to present and report on live football for the BBC and Logan now deputises for [[Gary Lineker]] on [[Match of the Day]]. Logan hosted ''[[Final Score]]'' from 2009 until 2013 before being replaced by [[Jason Mohammad]]. When Craig Doyle left BBC Sport to go to ITV in 2008 the BBC needed a new host for the 6 Nations with 2 or 3 matches being broadcast every weekend therefore Gabby Logan was recruited, she previously reported on the 2003 Rugby World Cup for ITV and works alongside the likes of Jeremy Guscott, Keith Wood, Jonathan Davies & Andy Nicol.{{Cite web |url=http://www.gabbylogan.com/biography |title=Biography |website=Gabby Logan Official |accessdate=17 November 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141129021045/http://www.gabbylogan.com/biography |archive-date=29 November 2014 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} Logan is the now{{when|date=February 2018}} the main host of Athletics for [[BBC Sport]]. Amongst her main duties, has been hosting live coverage of the [[2013 World Championships in Athletics|World Athletics Championships]] in 2013,{{Cite web |url=http://sport-onthebox.com/2013/08/05/iaaf-world-athletics-championships-2013-live-on-the-bbc/ |title=IAAF World Athletics Championships 2013 live on the BBC |website=Sport on the Box |date=8 May 2013 |accessdate=19 September 2013}} and the [[2014 European Athletics Championships|European Athletics Championships]] and [[Athletics at the 2014 Commonwealth Games|Commonwealth Games]] in 2014.{{cite web |url=http://sport-onthebox.com/2014/04/07/bbc-sport-announces-2014-athletics-coverage/ |title=BBC Sport Announces 2014 Athletics Coverage |website=Sport on the Box |date=7 April 2014 |accessdate=17 November 2014}} Also included is the prestigious annual [[IAAF Diamond League]] season competition. She presents in the BBC Studio alongside Michael Johnson, Paula Radcliffe, Colin Jackson, Denise Lewis and Baroness Tanni Grey-Thompson. Gabby Logan hosted Games Today between 7.00pm-8.00pm at the 2008 Olympic Games for the BBC and hosted Olympics Tonight between 10.40pm-12.00am again for the BBC. Logan has reported from the England Camp for the 2010 World Cup, Euro 2012 and World Cup 2014 while also being a pitchside reporter at the venues when England are playing. Being a sports presenter, Logan has also hosted live coverage of other sporting events such as the [[2013 FINA World Championships|2013 Aquatics World Championships]]{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/swimming/23331442 |title=World Aquatics Championships |website=BBC Sport |accessdate=17 November 2014}} Since 2009, Logan has been a frequent stand-in presenter on ''[[The One Show]]'' on [[BBC One]]. In August 2013, Logan began hosting the [[BBC One]] series ''[[I Love My Country (UK TV series)|I Love My Country]]'', featuring team captains [[Micky Flanagan]] and [[Frank Skinner]] on Saturday evenings, however, on 25 October 2013, the programme was axed due to largely negative press reviews and poor viewing figures.{{cite web |url=http://www.comedy.co.uk/news/story/000001273/that_puppet_game_show_i_love_my_country_axed/ |title=BBC axes That Puppet Game Show and I Love My Country |website=[[British Comedy Guide]] |accessdate=25 October 2013}} In September 2013, the BBC announced that, as of 2013, Logan would replace [[Sue Barker]] as one of the presenters for the annual [[BBC Sports Personality of the Year]].{{cite web |url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/tv/news/a516438/sue-barker-steps-down-from-hosting-bbc-sports-personality-of-the-year.html |title=Sue Barker steps down from hosting BBC Sports Personality of the Year |website=Digital Spy |date=18 September 2013 |accessdate=19 September 2013}} In March 2015, Logan hosted ''[[Let's Play Darts for Comic Relief]]'' for [[BBC Two]].{{cite web |url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/tv/news/a587157/gabby-logan-to-host-lets-play-darts-for-comic-relief-in-2015.html |title=Gabby Logan to host Let's Play Darts for Comic Relief in 2015 |website=Digital Spy |date= |accessdate=29 July 2014}} The show returned for a second series in February 2016.{{cite web |url=http://www.comedy.co.uk/news/story/000001915/lets_play_darts_sport_relief_2016/ |title=Let's Play Darts to return for Sport Relief |website=British Comedy Guide |date=8 October 2015 |accessdate=7 December 2017}} She presented live coverage of the [[2015 London Marathon]], broadcast on [[BBC One]] on 26 April, the [[2016 London Marathon]] on 24 April and the [[2017 London Marathon]] on 23 April. In August 2015, she was the main presenter for BBC's coverage of the [[IAAF World Championships in Athletics]] from Beijing. Logan presented the second series of the BBC game show ''[[The Edge (game show)|The Edge]]'' in 2015. She replaced [[Mark Benton]] who hosted series 1.{{cite web |url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/tv/news/a668094/gabby-logan-is-taking-over-from-mark-benton-as-presenter-of-bbc-ones-the-edge-this-autumn.html |title=Gabby Logan to host The Edge this autumn |date=11 September 2015 |website=Digital Spy |accessdate=7 December 2017}} In 2016, Logan was part of the presenting team for [[Invictus Games|The Invictus Games]] on [[BBC One]]. She was also a part of the media team during the BBC's coverage of the 2016 [[UEFA European Championship]] in [[France]]. In 2017 she hosted the BBC IAAF coverage in London. ===Channel 5=== In June 2011, while still presenting the sports results shows for [[BBC One]] on Saturdays, Logan joined [[Channel 5 (UK)|Channel 5]] to present a discussion and magazine show following ''[[The Wright Stuff]]'' at 11:10 am each weekday initially called ''The Wright Stuff Extra'', and later renamed as ''Live with Gabby''.{{cite web |url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/tv/news/a326090/gabby-logan-to-host-channel-5-wright-stuff-spinoff.html |title=Gabby Logan to host Channel 5 'Wright Stuff' spinoff |website=Digital Spy |date=22 June 2011 |accessdate=26 August 2014}} On 5 April 2012, the show tweeted to confirm that Logan was leaving the programme.{{cite web |url=https://twitter.com/LivewithGabby |title=Live With Gabby |website=[[Twitter]] |accessdate=27 October 2014}} ==Filmography== ===Television=== {| class="wikitable" |- style="background:#b0c4de; text-align:center;" ! Her previous Sunday morning was taken over by [[Kate Silverton]]. On 20 October 2009, it was announced that Logan would be leaving her Sunday morning slot on [[BBC Radio 5 Live]] and starting a new weekday show on the station from 12:00 noon to 2:00 pm (Monday–Friday) which began on 11 January 2010. {{citation needed|date=October 2013}} In light of the move of [[BBC Radio 5 Live]] from London to [[MediaCityUK]] in [[Salford Quays|Salford]], Logan left her weekday show in April 2011 due to other BBC work and family commitments. She was replaced by [[Shelagh Fogarty]]. On 12 April 2009, she presented the [[BBC]] [[Radio 4 Appeal]] on behalf of [[St John's Catholic School for the Deaf]].{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b00jlwnz |title=BBC Radio 4 Appeal |accessdate=23 April 2009}}{{cite news |url=http://www.yorkshirepost.co.uk/health/Gabby-adds-her-support-to.5154450.jp |title=Gabby adds her support to school appeal |newspaper=Yorkshire Post |date=8 April 2009 |accessdate=23 April 2009}} ==Other work== [[File:2012 Hours To Go Gabby Logan.jpg|thumb|Gabby Logan hosting the [[London Olympic Stadium]] opening ceremony in 2012.]] In December 2012, Logan was appointed as a non-executive director of [[Perform Group]].{{cite web |title=Perform Appoints Non-Executive Director |url=http://otp.investis.com/clients/uk/performgroup/rns/regulatory-story.aspx?cid=431&newsid=294323 |website=Investis.com |accessdate=1 January 2013 |date=3 December 2012}} In 2014, Logan helped launch Tesco's Farm to Fork initiative.{{cite web |url=http://www.gabbylogan.com/news/2014/01/29/gabby-helps-launch-farm-to-fork-initiative/6159 |title=Gabby helps launch Farm to Fork initiative |website=Gabby Logan.com |date=29 January 2014 |accessdate=29 July 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140221142523/http://www.gabbylogan.com/news/2014/01/29/gabby-helps-launch-farm-to-fork-initiative/6159 |archive-date=21 February 2014 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} Logan is the [[voice-over]] for the MegaRed heart health commercial advertisements.{{cite web |url=http://www.gabbylogan.com/news/2014/02/06/gabby-speaks-to-juice-fm-1076-about-heart-health/6161 |title=Gabby speaks to Juice FM 107.6 about heart health |website=Gabby Logan.com |date=6 February 2014 |accessdate=29 July 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140223050356/http://www.gabbylogan.com/news/2014/02/06/gabby-speaks-to-juice-fm-1076-about-heart-health/6161 |archive-date=23 February 2014 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} Logan writes regularly for ''[[The Times]]'' newspaper.
